slides.text: When’s the last time you changed the password on your email account?

slides.title: Cold Hard Facts
slides.text:
Twent-one percent of internet users use passwords that they haven’t changed in 10 years!

For context, Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie were still together the last time they changed their password.

slides.title: Cold Hard Facts #2
slides.text: You’d also be surprised at what the most common passwords leaked in 2016 data breaches were...

slides.title: How many people used these passwords?
slides.text: Believe it or not, over 50% of users in these breaches used these passwords.

slides.title: Not so fast...
slides.text:
You might be thinking to yourself, "I don’t use any of these passwords, so I should be fine."

That’s a dangerous assumption! As we will demonstrate in this module, some passwords that seem secure may actually be extremely easy to crack!

slides.title: Why Secure Passwords Matter
slides.text: It’s also easy to believe that you are not a lucrative target, making it difficult to conceive that someone would want to break into your online accounts. It may be hard to incentivize yourself to change your password to something more secure.

slides.title: Risks of an Insecure Account
slides.text: However, do you really want your personal information to become accessible to strangers?

slides.title: Module Overview
slides.text: This module will teach you how easy it is to crack some passwords and provide you with tips for constructing more secure passwords. It will also introduce you to password managers, which are programs that generate strong passwords and save you the trouble of remembering all of them!
In this section, we’re going to show you how frequently people make passwords that are easy to guess through brute force. We’ll also show you how quickly one can crack a password you think is secure!

slides.title: Password Length
slides.text: Most websites prescribe a minimum password length of 8 characters. As it turns out, 61% of users create a password that just meets that limit.

slides.title: Password Composition
slides.text: On average, these passwords consist of 1.1 upper-case letters, 6.1 lower-case letters, 2.2 numbers and 0.2 special characters.

slides.title: How quick is this to crack?
slides.text:
So, this means there are 26 lowercase letters, 26 uppercase letters, and 10 digits that most frequently are in a password (special characters are infrequent enough that we will not include them in this calculation).

26+26+10 = 62

This means there are 628 combinations of passwords that the typical internet user would pick from. That sounds like a LOT, right?

slides.title: The Danger of Dictionary Words
slides.text:
An attacker can even speed up this process by guessing dictionary words that may be in your password. Instead of testing all possible combinations of letters and numbers, the attacker can run your passwords against a list of dictionary words.

Given that there are 252,200 words in the Oxford english dictionary and that the average user uses 2 numbers in their password, there are approximately 25 MILLION possible password combinations based on dictionary words.

slides.text: Out of 25,200,000 possible password combinations, and 2,800,000,000 password tests a second, approximately how long do you think it would take to hack a dictionary word-based password?

options.feedback: It would take a hacker with a fast computer less than one second to hack a dictionary word-based password. Whatever you do, don't set your password to be "kitten123."

slides.text: Seventy-five percent of passwords are simply composed of dictionary words. This means that the majority of passwords can be cracked under a second! Clearly, most internet users need to use more secure passwords.

slides.title: Check Your Password Security
slides.text: The website How Secure Is My Password can tell you how long it would take for your password to get cracked. Why don’t you try it with a test password that uses the same number of lowercase, uppercase, and numeric characters that one of your passwords uses? You might be shocked by the result!
Now that we’ve learned how simple it can be to crack a weak password, it’s crucial to learn how to generate more secure ones.
Luckily, creating stronger passwords is fairly simple. This section of the module will teach you how to make easy-to-remember, hard-to-guess passwords.

slides.title: Length Matters
slides.text: The key to designing more secure passwords is to increase their size. Consider a password that uses uppercase letters, lowercase letters, and numeric characters. Every time a password has an extra character, it is harder to guess by a factor of (26 + 26 + 10) = 62!

slides.title: Longer Passwords are Harder to Remember
slides.text: The caveat of longer passwords is that they are harder to remember. Can you imagine remembering a random 15-character password like the one on the right?

slides.text: A fifteen character random password is difficult to break, even by guessing every possible password with the fastest possible computer program! However, these passwords can be difficult to remember. Let’s explore some easier ways to create secure passwords.

slides.title: Intro to Diceware Passwords
slides.text: Diceware passwords combine the best of both worlds. They are longer passwords that are more secure but still easy to remember.

slides.title: What’s a diceware password?
slides.text:
Creating a diceware password involves choosing six words at random. First, you roll a die five times, recording each output. For example, rolling 1, 3, 2, 2, 5 gives you the number 13225. Then, you look at the diceware vocabulary list and select the word corresponding to the number '13225'. This process is repeated five more times.

[link to diceware list: http://world.std.com/~reinhold/diceware.html]

slides.title: Example Diceware Password
slides.text: For instance, the numbers 16665 15653 56322 35616 16662 21126  map to the password 'cleft cam synod lacy clean cloak'.

slides.title: QUIZ: how hard is it to crack a diceware password?
slides.question: With 2,800,000,000 password tests a second, how long would it take to brute-force guess a six-word long diceware password?

slides.text: Six-word long diceware passwords are almost impossible to guess through brute-force. And even four-word long diceware passwords would take almost a year to guess through brute-force!

slides.title: Section Conclusion
slides.text: We've learned that longer passwords are extremely secure and very difficult to brute-force guess. However, we also have to acknowledge that even remembering a diceware password isn’t easy. What if there was an easier solution for managing long and secure passwords?
